member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ICalStationDriver.downloadCalAndBumpData(System.Collections.ArrayList,System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Downloads then clears all Calibration and Bump Test data from the calibration station.
member.param: For each calibration record read from the calibration station, this method will add an instance (or a subclass instance) to the passed-in ArrayList.
For each bump test record read from the calibration station, this method will add an instance (or a subclass instance) to the passed-in ArrayList.
member.returns: And empty string is returned if everything is successful. An error string is returned if an error occurs when trying to download or clear the data from the cal station.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusDriver.SetAbortRequester(ISC.Instrument.Driver.AbortRequest)
member.summary:
Specify a delegate that can be used by the driver to determine if if should abort communications. Whenever the driver encounters a communications error, it will immediately call the specified AbortRequest delegate.
See the documentation for the AbortRequest delegate for more details on how to use.
member.param: If null is passed, then a NullAbortRequest is used.

member.summary: Returns a count of how many times TxRx failed and had to retry.
member.remarks: Note that for the docking station, the value returned comes from the ModbusLibrary DLL. The value is cumulative; i.e., it never resets back to zero and will only continually increment as the docking station continues to run.

member.name: F:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.Y2K
member.summary: January 1st, 2000.
member.remarks:
Used internally for determining number of seconds since 1/1/2000, and sometimes used as an baseline for adding/subtracting a number of years to the year 2000.
(Dates returned by the instruments (such as setup date) are often all relative to 1/1/2000.)
NOTE / TODO: Don't know if hardcoding of year 2000 will work on OS's that are not using Gregorian calender (such as Windows running Saudi Arabia local)!

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Establishes communication with the instrument.
member.param:
If true is specified, then this method will initiate a "batch connection".
If false is specified, then non-batched connection is performed.
Note that many of the overrides of this abstract method that are in the various InstrumentDriver subclasses completely ignore this parameter. Please check documentation for each override for specifics.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.disconnect
member.summary: Intended to be called by Dispose. Does a BatchDisconnect (if necessary), or any other logic that needs to be done to 'disconnect' from an instrument before we close the serial port.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.shutdown
member.summary: Turns off (powers down) the instrument. If the instrument does not have the ability to be turned off, then this method will do nothing.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.saveInstrumentSettings
member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks:
Only instrument settings need to be explicitly saved by calling this.
Changing sensor settings happens immediately, and this does not need to be called for sensors.
Clearing instrument logs is also immediate, and this does not need to be called for them.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.

remarks.para: This is not the same as enabling/disabling or pausing/unpausing sensors. This is telling the instrument to actually send/kill power to the sensors to activate/stop them.
Only some instruments allow their sensors to be powered on or off. For those instruments that do not, this method will do nothing.

member.param: True to turn on the sensors; False to turn them off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getEquipmentType
member.summary: Returns the type of equipment that the driver is communicating with. The returned type is what the device claims it is when it is queried by this method.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getEquipmentSubType
member.summary: Returns the instrument's sub-type. i.e., some instruments of a specific type can be of a different "sub type". For example, a 5-gas VentisPro, versus a 4-gas VentisPro. Or a standard MX6, versus a Benzene (Garcia) MX6.
member.returns: Some instruments do not have "sub types". This default implementation, used for those instruments, always just returns .

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.setWirelessActiveChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets mask to specify which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getWirelessActiveChannelMask
member.summary: Returns a mask specifying which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.returns:
Each bit of this returned value is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Bits are set to 1 for the allowed channels, or are set to 0 for the disallowed channels.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.setWirelessListeningPostChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.
member.remarks: This method should not be called if returns false.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getWirelessListeningPostChannelMask
member.summary: Gets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.
member.remarks: This method should not be called if returns false.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Bits are set to 1 for the allowed channels, or are set to 0 for the disallowed channels.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getMagneticFieldDuration
member.summary: Returns the instrument's current "Magnetic field duration" setting.
member.remarks:
If the instrument detects no Modbus communications within this number of seconds after its reed switch indicates it's been docked, then the instrument disregards the reed switch indication as a "false docking". This is to avoid problems where reed switch sometimes closes when usser carries the instrument into an environment with a strong magnetic field. then the instrument considers the dock.
should be called first to determine if it is safe to call this method.
member.returns: Value is in seconds.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.setMagneticFieldDuration(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the instrument's "Magnetic field duration" setting.
member.remarks:
If the instrument detects no Modbus communications within this number of seconds after its reed switch indicates it's been docked, then the instrument disregards the reed switch indication as a "false docking". This is to avoid problems where reed switch sometimes closes when a user carries the instrument into an environment with a strong magnetic field. then the instrument considers the dock.
should be called first to determine if it is safe to call this method.
member.param: Value is in seconds and must be within range defined by MinMagneticFieldDuration"/> and MaxMagneticFieldDuration. Otherwise, specified value will be auto-adjusted to the correct value (either MinMagneticFieldDuration or MaxMagneticFieldDuration). adjusted to be within the range.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.setAlarmActionMessages(ISC.Instrument.Driver.AlarmActionMessageGroup[])
member.summary: Sets the various text messages that the instrument displays for each of its sensor's Alert, Low, High, STEL and TWA alarms.
member.remarks: This method should only be called if returns a value greater than zero.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.InstrumentDriver.getSensorBiasStatus
member.summary: Indicates if all the sensors that need to be biased are, and the instrument is ready for gas operations (zero, calibrate, bump, etc.).
member.remarks:
Some sensors, such as VentisPro's lead-free O2 sensors, are biased sensors that require constant power to get accurate readings. If the instrument's battery dies, then when the instrument is charged enough that the sensors can be turned on again, the biased sensors will likely be in OR for some time. Once the readings are low enough that the sensor is no longer in OR, it will still require some additional time before the readings are accurate enough where a reliable calibration or bump can be performed. Calibrating a biased sensor too soon can result in an improper calibration.
Docking stations needing to perform a gas operation (bump test, zeroing, calibration, etc.), should first call this getSensorBiasMethod before to determine if any sensors need biasing. If the method indicates that biasing is currently in progress, then this method should be repeated called until the biasing either completed, or it fails.
This method can be called for all instrument types. It will merely return SensorBiasStatus.Ready for instruments that do not use biased sensors.
BEFORE CALLING THIS METHOD, IT IS IMPORTANT TO FIRST CALL , IN ORDER TO FIRST FULLY WARM UP THE SENSORS.
member.returns:
Docking stations should continually call this method while InProgress is returned.
Once Ready is returned, then the gas operation can proceed.
If Failed is returned, then the gas operation should not proceed.

member.summary: Sets the baud rate to be used for communicating with the instrument.
member.exception: If an illegal baud rate is specified.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.summary: For this instrument type, this method verifies that the instrument is able to communicate. It does NOT turn on the instrument, though, as the instrument automatically powers on when it's docked and charged enough, and it cannot be powered off when it is docked.
member.remarks: This instrument type will communicate without being "turned on" when it knows it is docked. This method merely verifies that the instrument is able to communicate. (The instrument would fail to communicate, for example, if its battery is dead.)
member.param:
Ignored by this instrument type. For this instrument type, a "batched connection" is always established. We can get away with always doing "batched connections", for this instrument type because once the instrument is set to a high baud rate, we don't have to worry about it "timing out" and reverting to a slower baud rate if nothing talks to it for a while. i.e., once it goes to higher baud rate, it will stay at that baud rate.
Additional caveat: The instrument may revert to a slow baud rate if sees "garbage" Irda packets being sent to it, as it assumes the garbage data might be something trying to talk to it at a slow baud rate. When this happens (rarely), the driver is able to recover and re-connect relatively quickly.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.shutdown
member.remarks: This instrument type cannot be commanded to power down when it's docked. Instead, for this instrument type, this method tells the instrument to go to mode, which should cause the instrument to turn of its sensors (if they've been turned on) so that it will charge faster.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.saveInstrumentSettings
member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks: For this instrument type, this method doesn't do anything, since the instrument automatically saves any changed settings to flash when it is undocked.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.
member.remarks:
When called, this method tells the instrument to power on its sensor by setting its operating mode .
It powers off the sensors by setting its operating mode to .
member.param: Specify true to turn on, false to turn off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to warmup.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.pauseSensor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Pause/unpause the specified sensor. When paused, sensor does not read gas.

member.name: P:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Driver.HasShutdownFeature
member.summary: Indicates if the instrument can be turned off or not, via a modbus command.
member.remarks:
Always returns false. But, actually, the instrument CAN be turned off. But it was decided that datalink should not be allowed to, so this property lies, and returns false even when the real answer is true.
Making this return false just for the Accessory Software when the instrument can actually shutdown was the wrong thing to do. It causes the property to be specific to the Accessory Software, and useless to all other software. If the Accessory Software didn't like this property returning "the truth", then we should have made the Accessory Software deal with that problem in its own code. - JMP - 3/2012.

Pump flow set point is a mV reading that pump has to get within 5% of in order to run at proper flow.

member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks:
Only instrument settings need to be explicitly saved by calling this.
Changing sensor settings happens immediately, and this does not need to be called for sensors.
Clearing instrument logs is also immediate, and this does not need to be called for them.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.
member.remarks: When called, this method powers on the sensors by setting its operating mode to . It powers off the sensors by setting its operating mode to .
member.param: Specify true to turn on, false to turn off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to warmup after a sufficient amount of time waiting for it to do.

When commanded to "warm up", this instrument type will run a self test. The self test may result in the instrument entering a SystemAlarm state that it will never leave until undocked. If this alarm state is detected, SystemAlarmException will be thrown. Its ErrorCode property will contain the error code that the instrument has reported.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.setWirelessCustomEncryptionKey(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the wireless module's custom encryption key.
member.param:
A hexadecimal string representing the encryption key's bytes. e.g. Maximum of 32 hex characters. (The encryption key is 128 bits. That equates to 16 bytes. 16 bytes represented as hex equates to 32 characters.)
If the passed-in string is longer than 32 characters, then the extra characters will be ignored.
If a null or empty string is passed in, then the module's custom encryption key will be set to all zeroes.
member.exception: If the passed-in string contains any non-hexadecimal characters.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessCustomEncryptionKey
member.summary: Returns the wireless module's custom encryption key.
member.returns:
A hexadecimal string representing the encryption key's bytes.
If the encryption key is all zeroes, then an empty string is returned.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.setWirelessMessageHops(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the number of hops a wireless message can take in a given network.
member.remarks: Each time the message hops from one instrument to the next the value is decremented until the value is 0 - then the message is no longer forwarded.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessMessageHops
member.summary: Gets the number of hops a wireless message can take in a given network.
member.remarks: Each time the message hops from one instrument to the next the value is decremented until the value is 0 - then the message is no longer forwarded.

member.summary: Returns the maxiumum number of peers allowed in a wireless network.

member.summary: Set the wireless primary channel.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessPrimaryChannel
member.summary: Returns the wireless primary channel.
member.remarks: Corresponds to a single channel in the wireless frequency band; value will correspond to bit number in active channel mask.
member.returns: A value from 0 to 15.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.setWirelessSecondaryChannel(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Set the wireless secondary channel.
member.remarks: Corresponds to a single channel in the wireless frequency band.
member.param: Value from 0 to 15. If no secondary channel used, set to 255. The value (if not 255) will correspond to bit number in active channel mask.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessSecondaryChannel
member.summary: Returns the wireless secondary channel.
member.remarks: Corresponds to a single channel in the wireless frequency band.
member.returns: A value from 0 to 15. If no secondary channel used, then 255. The value (if not 255) will correspond to bit number in active channel mask.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.setWirelessActiveChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets mask to specify which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessActiveChannelMask
member.summary: Returns a mask specifying which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.returns:
Each bit of this returned value is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Bits are set to 1 for the allowed channels, or are set to 0 for the disallowed channels.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.setWirelessListeningPostChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.
member.remarks: This method should not be called if returns false.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.
member.exception: Thrown if firmare version is less than 3.00.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.getWirelessListeningPostChannelMask
member.summary: Gets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.
member.remarks: This method should not be called if returns false.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.
member.exception: Thrown if firmare version is less than 3.00.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreDriver.isWirelessFeatureEnabled
member.summary: Returns whether the instrument's wireless feature is enabled or not (i.e. unlocked/locked).
member.remarks: The wireless feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the wireless hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasWirelessFeature returns true.
member.returns: True if wireless features are unlocked/enabled. False if locked/disabled.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.param: True to unlock/enable the wireless features. False to lock/disable the wireless features.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreFactoryDriver.configureSensors
member.summary: Configures the duel sensors' settings so that they are in sync with each other.
member.remarks:
Calling this method causes the instrument to read the settings for its installed duel sensors, determine any differences between the pairs, then modifying (if necessary) any settings on them in order to make the settings the same between them.
The sensors "settings" are fields such as Low, High, STEL, and TWA alarms and, also, the peak reading.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreFactoryDriver.getDualSenseCalRequestedFlag
member.summary: Returns the instrument's "cal requested" flag.
member.remarks: When the two sensors in dual sense mode have huge differences in their individual readings, the instrument assumes they need to be calibrated - because maybe one is bad - so, the instrument set's a flag for itself. It causes the Cal Due alert when set.
member.returns: True if the flag is set; else false.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreFactoryDriver.setDualSenseCalRequestedFlag(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the instrument's "cal requested" flag.
member.remarks:
When the two sensors in dual sense mode have huge differences in their individual readings, the instrument assumes they need to be calibrated - because maybe one is bad - so, the instrument set's a flag for itself. It causes the Cal Due alert when set.
This method allows an the flag the be set externally by an application; this is necessary and only intended for configuring the instrument.
member.param: True to set the flag, false to clear the flag

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.SafeCoreFactoryDriver.setResetCount(System.Int32)

member.remarks: Intended to be used when configuring the instrument (to set it to zero), and for restoring the value during firmware upgrades.

Where messages actually go to is dependent on how the tracer is implemented. e.g., a tracer may may perhaps send messages to a serial port (for hyperterminal logging), or to a text log file, etc.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.DriverInstrumentCalibrationRecord
member.summary: For the calibration records, the span reserve, instrument serial number, sensor type, sensor status (which gives the pass/fail), date, and time. This is the data that is printed out. I also read the cal gas type, cal gas high limit, and the cal gas value to determine some of the pass/fail for the bump test. It would be nice to pass the sensor serial number back too.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Establishes communication with the instrument.
member.param:
If true is specified, then this method will initiate a "batch connection".
If false is specified, then non-batched connection is performed. It's recommended to use baud rate of 9600 for non-batched connections.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.
member.remarks:
When called, this method tells the instrument to power on its sensor by setting its operating mode .
It powers off the sensors by setting its operating mode to .
member.param: Specify true to turn on, false to turn off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to warmup.

member.summary: Sets the Bump Interval (in days) for the instrument.

member.exception: If instrument firmware version does not support this field.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.getInstrumentDiagnostics
member.summary: Executes and returns the results of a series of instrument diagnostics tests.
member.returns:
An array of objects.
For this instrument type, the returned diagnostics have the following Codes...
BatteryVoltage
BatteryStatus
Speaker1Voltage
Speaker2Voltage
VibratingAlarmVoltage

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.setSensorGasCode(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Configures a sensor to detect a particular type of gas.
member.remarks:
For this instrument type, this method is used for setting a PID sensor's "response factor" or an LEL sensor's "correlation factor".
This method should only be called if returns true.
member.param: Format is "Gxxxx" where 'x' is digits 0 or greater. e.g. "G0091"

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.beginInstrumentCalibration
member.summary: Put instrument into calibration mode. Once instrument is in calibration mode, it's expected that beginSensorCalibration will be subsequently called for each sensor to calibrate.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.endInstrumentCalibration
member.summary: Take instrument out of calibration mode. This routine should be called either at the end of calibrating all sensors, or to abort calibration mode while in the middle of calibrating a particular sensor.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.beginInstrumentBump
member.summary: Called prior to performing an instrument bump test. If anything needs done prior to bump testing an instrument, it should be done here.
member.remarks: This method does nothing for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.endInstrumentBump
member.summary: Called after performing an instrument bump test. If anything needs done prior to bump testing an instrument, it should be done here.
member.remarks: MX6 Override. Set all sensors to run mode. v4.4

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.beginSensorBump(System.Int32)
member.summary: Begin Bump Test on specified sensor.
member.remarks: MX6 override. v4.4

member.summary: Begin calibration on specified sensor. Requires that beginInstrumentCalibration be called previously to put instrument into calibration mode.
member.param: The sensor position to calibrate. (For this instrument type, only the first element in the passed-in eenumerable is used.)

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.endSensorCalibration(System.Int32)
member.summary: End calibration on specified sensor. Requires that beginCalibration be called previously to put instrument/sensor into calibration mode.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.isSensorCalibrating(System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates if specified sensor is currently calibrating.

member.summary: Indicates pass/fail of last bump test operating on specified sensor.

member.name: P:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6Driver.HasShutdownFeature
member.summary: Indicates if the instrument can be turned off or not, via a modbus command.
member.remarks:
Always returns false. But, actually, the instrument CAN be shutdown. But it was decided that datalink should not be allowed to, so this property lies, and returns false even when the real answer is true.
Making this return false just for the ISAS software when the instrument can actually shutdown was the wrong thing to do. It makes the method specific to the ISAS software and useless to all other software. If ISAS didn't like it returning "the truth", then we should have made ISAS deal with that problem in its own code. - JMP - 3/2012.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6FactoryDriver.beginBatteryConfiguration
member.summary: Places the battery pack into configuration mode.
member.remarks: To configure the battery, we must first place it into configuration mode. Then need to program the battery mode, serial number, part number, setup date, tech initials, and manufacturer. To configure the battery the battery mode must be set to a 0x10 then the five parameters set. Once all five are set, the battery pack will automatically exit configuration mode.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6FactoryDriver.endBatteryConfiguration
member.summary: Takes the battery pack out of configuration mode.
member.remarks: Theoretically, the battery pack should automatically come out of configuration mode on its own once all required parameters are set. This routine can be used to force it, though, should the board ever stay 'stuck' in configuration mode.

member.summary: Returns the wireless transmission interval setting.
member.returns: Note that this method always return zero if the instrument is not running v4.30 or newer firmware.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx6FactoryDriver.setWirelessTransmissionInterval(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the wireless transmission interval setting.
member.remarks: Note that this method will do nothing if the instrument is not running v4.30 or newer firmware.
member.param:
Valid range is 0 to 300 seconds. If passed-in interval is outside this range, then the instrument will just ignore it and keep its current interval setting.
If set to 0, then wireless transmissions are turned off.
If set to any other value between 1 and 300, then wireless transmissions will be sent each time the interval has lapsed.
Default value is 1 second.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver
member.summary: This driver is used for M40, M40m, and M40ma multi-gas instruments.
member.remarks: It is not used for the M40 Pro instrument.

member.summary: Default constructor.

member.summary: Constructor. Initializes driver using the specified COM port.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.disconnect
member.summary: For this instrument type, calling disconnect causes the Keep Alive thread to terminate.
member.remarks: After calling, the result is the instrument will automatically turn off after aproximately two minutes if no more modbus communications occur.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.DoKeepAlive
member.summary: Thread handler for background 'keep alive' thread. The Keep Alive thread 'pings' the M40 instrument every so many seconds to keep the instrument from turning off.
member.remarks: The M40 turns itself off automatically after aproximately two minutes of no modbus communication activity.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.saveInstrumentSettings
member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks: For this instrument type, this method doesn't do anything, since the instrument automatically saves any changed settings to flash when it is undocked.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.getSensorSupportedCalGasConc(System.Int32)
member.summary: For sensors allowing only particular cal gas concentrations (e.g. only 25 or 50), this method returns the concentrations that the sensor supports, otherwise null.
member.returns:
The values in the returned array are the only concentrations allowed for the specified sensor.
For this instrument type, if the specified sensor is an LEL sensor, and if the instrument is an M40 (i.e., not M40m or M40ma), then this method will return 25 and 50.
A null will be returned in all other cases.

member.returns: Calibration gas concentration for the specific sensor

member.returns: Only returns true for M40's LEL sensor; otherwise false.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.setSensorCalGasCode(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the sensor's calibration gas code.
member.param: Format is "Gxxxx" where 'x' is digits 0 or greater. e.g. "G0021"
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.M40Driver.setSensorCalGasConcentration(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Set a sensor's calibration gas concentration.
member.remarks: The M40 instruments (but not M40m or M40ma) allow their LEL sensor's concentration to be changed to either 25% or 50% LEL. The driver handles this special case via a with EnabledCode of'lelcalconc'.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.shutdown
member.summary: Places the instrument into DockedLowPower mode.
member.remarks:
DockedLowPower mode causes the instrument's IrDA to be turned off, to save the battery. It therefore no longer resoonds to Modbus communication once it enteres DockedLowPower mode.
To re-establish communication with the instrument, must be called which will "blast" the instrument with IrDA packets to wake the instrument back up.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.saveInstrumentSettings
member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks: For this instrument type, this method doesn't do anything, since the instrument automatically saves any changed settings to flash when it is undocked.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.param:
Ignored by this instrument type. For this instrument type, a "batched connection" is always established. We can get away with always doing a batched connection, because once the instrument is set to a high baud rate, it will stay at that baud rate for up to 10 minutes. (If nothing talks to it for 10 minutes, it "times out" and turns off its IrDA at which point it needs to be "blasted" awake again.)
Additional caveat: The instrument may revert to a slow baud rate if sees "garbage" Irda packets being sent to it, as it assumes the garbage data might be something trying to talk to it at a slow baud rate. When this happens (rarely), the driver is able to recover and re-connect relatively quickly.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.setPortSpeed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the baud rate to be used for communicating with the instrument.
member.exception: If an illegal baud rate is specified.

member.summary: Change the instrument's current mode. i.e., make it start calibrating, or put it into bump test mode, etc.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.setOperatingMode(ISC.Instrument.Driver.OperatingMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Change the instrument's current mode. i.e., make it start calibrating, or put it into bump test mode, etc.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to go into the specified mode (i.e. if remains stuck in its current mode.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.
member.remarks: When called, this method powers on the instrument by setting its operating mode to . It powers off the instrument by setting its operating mode to .
member.param: Specify true to turn on, false to turn off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to warmup.

member.summary: Returns the instrument's current Maintenance Indicator Interval in minutes

Number of minutes between the sounding of the bump,cal or dock overdue indicators

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.setMaintenanceIndicatorInterval(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the instrument's Maintenance Indicator Interval
member.remarks:
Number of minutes between the sounding of the bump,cal or dock overdue indicators
This method should only be called if returns true.
member.param: Value is in minutes and must be within range defined by MinMaintenanceIndicatorInterval and MaxMaintenanceIndicatorInterval. Otherwise, specified value will be auto-adjusted to the correct value (either MinMaintenanceIndicatorInterval or MaxMaintenanceIndicatorInterval). adjusted to be within the range.
member.exception: NotSupportedException will be thrown if instrument is not running v1.8 or newer firmware.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.getMagneticFieldDuration
member.summary: Returns the instrument's current "Magnetic field duration" setting.
member.remarks:
If the instrument detects no Modbus communications within this number of seconds after its reed switch indicates it's been docked, then the instrument disregards the reed switch indication as a "false docking". This is to avoid problems where reed switch sometimes closes when usser carries the instrument into an environment with a strong magnetic field. then the instrument considers the dock.
This setting is only used if instrument's "MAG" option is currently enabled.
member.returns: Value is in seconds.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.setMagneticFieldDuration(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the instrument's "Magnetic field duration" setting.
member.remarks:
If the instrument detects no Modbus communications within this number of seconds after its reed switch indicates it's been docked, then the instrument disregards the reed switch indication as a "false docking". This is to avoid problems where reed switch sometimes closes when a user carries the instrument into an environment with a strong magnetic field. then the instrument considers the dock.
This setting is only used if the instrument's "MAG" option is currently enabled.
member.param: Value is in seconds and must be within range defined by MinMagneticFieldDuration"/> and MaxMagneticFieldDuration. Otherwise, specified value will be auto-adjusted to the correct value (either MinMagneticFieldDuration or MaxMagneticFieldDuration). adjusted to be within the range.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.isWirelessFeatureEnabled
member.summary: Returns whether the instrument's wireless feature is enabled or not (i.e. unlocked/locked).
member.remarks: The wireless feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the wireless hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasWirelessFeature returns true.
member.returns: True if wireless features are unlocked/enabled. False if locked/disabled.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1Driver.enableWirelessFeature(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the instrument's wireless feature.
member.remarks: The wireless feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the wireless hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasWirelessFeature returns true.
member.param: True to unlock/enable the wireless features. False to lock/disable the wireless features.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.returns: True if bluetooth features are unlocked/enabled. False if locked/disabled.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.#ctor
member.summary: Default ctor.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor. Initializes driver using the specified COM port.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.factoryShutdown
member.summary: Places the instrument into factory sleep mode.
member.remarks:
When instrument is in factory sleep mode, it will continue to respond to Modbus communication until it is undocked.
When undocked, the instrument will automatically power down, even if the AlwaysOn option is enabled, and if the security code is set.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.beginConfiguration
member.summary: Placed the instrument into mode.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument will not enter mode.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.InitConfiguration
member.summary: This method is called by beginConfiguration write after the instrument reports in in FactoryUnitialized mode. The intent of this method is to all the driver to do some preliminary factory initialization of the instrument that application developers shouldn't have to worry about, such as zeroing certain registers, etc.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.endConfiguration
member.summary: This method should be called at the end of configuring the instrument. The methods waits for the instrument to exit mode.
member.remarks: The instrument is considered configured if its mode changes to either or . The instrument will change to these modes after being successfully configured because it automatically reboots itself, which then causes it to go through its warmup routine.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument remains stuck in mode or enters an unexpected mode.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.CheckConfigParameters
member.summary: This is a helper method for endConfiguration().
member.remarks: After an instrument is configured, it instrument saves the newly configured register values to flash memory and then reboots. Once this happens, its firmware needs to read the parameters back out of the flash memory. This routine polls the CONFIG_PARAMETERS_INITIALIZED register to 87 to determine when the instrument is done doing this. This register is 0 when the instrument is powered on. When the instrument parameters are completely read out of Flash memory, it is set to 1. If the instrument is set to Factory Uninitialized mode, the value is set to 0 again.

member.summary: Forces the instrument to reset itself.

member.summary: Sets the "temperature difference" value used by instrument's battery test algorithm.
member.remarks: If difference between the ambient temperature measured at time of battery test and current temperature is more than 10 degrees Celsius then battery test is performed and battery impedance is checked for fail threshold condition only.
member.returns: A celsius temperature difference

member.summary: Returns the impedance fail value used by instrument's battery test algorithm.
member.remarks: As part of the instrument's battery test, if the battery impedance is above the fail threshold then instrument enters intensive low battery warning for 10 minutes.
member.returns: Value is in milliohms.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.setBatteryFailImpedance(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets the impedance fail value used by instrument's battery test algorithm.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.getBatteryTestInterval
member.summary: Returns the "test interval" value used by instrument's battery test algorithm.
member.remarks: When low battery is detected then low battery warning is started. During low battery warning the battery test is performed at user settable interval - to check the battery status again.
member.returns: Number of minutes.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Tx1FactoryDriver.configureSensors
member.summary: Configures the duel sensors' settings so that they are in sync with each other.
member.remarks:
Calling this method causes the instrument to read the settings for its installed sensors, determine any differences between the two, then modifying (if necessary) any setting on them in order to make the settings the same between them.
The sensors "settings" are considered the Low, High, STEL, and TWA alarms and, also, the peak reading.

member.summary: TODO: what's this for?
member.returns:
The returned value may have one or more bits set to indicate which indicators have failed. IndicatorFailures.None is returned if there are no failures. The following bits are possible for this instrument type...
IndicatorFailures.LeftLed
IndicatorFailures.RightLed
IndicatorFailures.VibratingMotor
IndicatorFailures.Speaker
IndicatorFailures.Backlight
IndicatorFailures.Ram
IndicatorFailures.Flash
IndicatorFailures.DataFlash
IndicatorFailures.Sensor0Checksum
IndicatorFailures.Sensor1Checksum
IndicatorFailures.AmbientLightSensor
IndicatorFailures.BlueLed

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4DatalogPacketizer
member.summary: Manages the packets of hygiene data that are downloaded from instrument.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4DatalogPacketizer.Add(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Push a packet onto the end of the queue.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4DatalogPacketizer.Pop
member.summary: Remove the first packet at the front of the queue and return it.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4DatalogPacketizer.Peek
member.summary: Return the packet at the front of the queue, leaving it at the front of the queue.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4DatalogPacketizer.CheckCrc(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Each record has a CRC appended at the end. This is a CRC computed at the time the record was written to the instrument's dataflash. We need to check the CRC's to detect corrupt record. Any invalid CRCs mean we have a corrupt dataflash and the hygiene is invalid.
member.exception: Thrown if an invalid CRC is found

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VCalSixUnitCalStationDriver
member.summary: This driver is for the six-bay V-Cal calibration station.
member.remarks:
The six-bay Val is for use with Ventis instruments and, also, iQuads with standard or alkaline battery pack.
This driver supports the six-bay V-Cal. The parent class, , supports the single-bay V-Cal.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4CalStationDriver
member.summary: This driver is for the MX-Cal and single-bay V-Cal calibration stations.
member.remarks:
MX-Cal is a single-bay calibration station for use with MX4 iQuad.
V-Cal is a calibration station for use with Ventis instruments and, also, iQuads with standard or alkaline battery pack. This driver only supports the single-bay V-Cal. The supports the six-bay V-Cal calibrations station.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.CalPlusDriver

member.remarks: Cal Plus is a single-bay calibration station for use with Gas Badge Plus instruments.

member.summary: Called by constructor and public Dispose in order to implement standard IDisposable design pattern.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.CalPlusDriver.SetAbortRequester(ISC.Instrument.Driver.AbortRequest)
member.summary:
Specify a delegate that can be used by the driver to determine if if should abort communications. Whenever the driver encounters a communications error, it will immediately call the specified AbortRequest delegate.
See the documentation for the AbortRequest delegate for more details on how to use.
member.param: If null is passed, then a NullAbortRequest is used.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.CalPlusDriver.NullAbortRequest
member.summary: Default AbortRequest delegate. Always called unless overridden via with a different delegate via SetAbortRequester.
member.returns: Always returns false.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4CalStationDriver.ReadEepromRecords(System.Collections.ArrayList,System.Version,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads the calibration and bump data from the calibration station.
member.returns: A Modbus error code.
member.remarks: See notes on the protected overload of this function for details on retries for an MX-Cal/USB 1.1 bug.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4CalStationDriver.ReadEepromRecords(System.Collections.ArrayList,System.Version,System.Int32,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Reads the calibration and bump data from the calibration station.
member.param: The segment number on which to start the read.
The software version of the cal station.
member.returns: A Modbus error code.
member.remarks: This routine accepts a segment number as a parameter as a work around to a known issue with the MX-Cal station. When the MX-Cal station is connected to a computer through a USB 1.1 port (on the computer's side) the connection will be dropped while reading segments for the fifth record (segments 20-24). When this occurs, the public version of this method will call the method again, passing in the last segment number that the application attempted to read. The connection is reestablished and the read continues.

remarks.para: Note that this should always be enabled for all customers' instruments.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4FactoryDriver.setPumpFlowSetPoint(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the pump control set point for a Ventis instrument.
member.remarks:
Pump flow set point is a mV reading that pump has to get within 5% of in order to run at proper flow.
It is also set for Ventis LS even though it does not have a pump.
This method will do nothing if an attempt is made to set it for an iQuad.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4FactoryDriver.setWirelessTransmissionInterval(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the wireless module's transmission interval.
member.param: Must be a multiple of 5, and in range of 5 to 30. If invalid interval is specified, then default of 5 is used, instead.

member.remarks: Similar to .NET's "BitConverter" class.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToAsciiString(System.UInt16[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts contents of passed-in modbus registers to a string of characters. Registers assumed to contain two 8-bit characters apiece (hi/lo bytes).
member.param: Each register in the array is assumed to contain two 8-bit characters (hi/lo bytes).
member.returns: The returned string is trimmed of any trailing space or null characters.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToUnicodeString(System.UInt16[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts contents of passed-in modbus registers to a string of characters. Each registers assumed to contain one 16-bit character.
member.remarks: WARNING!! THIS FUNCTION HAS NEVER BEEN TESTED AS WE'VE NEVER NEEDED IT YET. NOT SURE IF BIG ENDIAN BYTE ORDER IS A PROPER ASSUMPTION.
member.param: Each registers assumed to contain one 16-bit character in big-endian byte order.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToAsciiRegisters(System.String,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Converts passed-in string to modbus registers containing two 8-bit characters per registers (high byte / low byte)
member.param: Max number of registers to return. If number of registers specified isn't large enough to hold the passed-in string then those characters that won't fit in the returned array are dropped.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToUnicodeRegisters(System.String,System.Int16)
member.summary: Converts passed-in string to modbus registers containing one 16-bit character per register.
member.remarks: WARNING!! THIS FUNCTION HAS NEVER BEEN TESTED AS WE'VE NEVER NEEDED IT YET. NOT SURE IF BIG ENDIAN BYTE ORDER IS A PROPER ASSUMPTION.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToInt16(System.Byte)

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToUInt16(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts first two bytes of passed-in array to an unsigned short.
member.returns: The returned value is in big-endian byte order.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusBitConverter.ToInt32(System.Byte)
member.summary: Converts the passed-in unsigned byte to a signed integer. e.g. A byte value of 248 is converted to an int value of -8.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.summary: Constructor. Initializes driver using the specified COM port.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.setPortSpeed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the baud rate to be used for communicating with the instrument.
member.exception: If an illegal baud rate is specified.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.summary: For this instrument type, this method verifies that the instrument is able to communicate. It does NOT turn on the instrument, though, as the instrument automatically powers on when it's docked and charged enough, and it cannot be powered off when it is docked.
member.remarks: This instrument type will communicate without being "turned on" when it knows it is docked. This method merely verifies that the instrument is able to communicate. (The instrument would fail to communicate, for example, if its battery is dead.)
member.param:
Ignored by this instrument type. For this instrument type, a "batched connection" is always established. We can get away with always doing "batched connections", for this instrument type because once the instrument is set to a high baud rate, we don't have to worry about it "timing out" and reverting to a slower baud rate if nothing talks to it for a while. i.e., once it goes to higher baud rate, it will stay at that baud rate.
Additional caveat: The instrument may revert to a slow baud rate if sees "garbage" Irda packets being sent to it, as it assumes the garbage data might be something trying to talk to it at a slow baud rate. When this happens (rarely), the driver is able to recover and re-connect relatively quickly.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.shutdown
member.remarks: This instrument type cannot be commanded to power down when it's docked. Instead, for this instrument type, this method tells the instrument to go to mode, which should cause the instrument to turn off its sensors (if they've been turned on) so that it will charge faster.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.saveInstrumentSettings
member.summary: This function should be called after changing any of an instrument's settings, in order to tell the instrument to save the modified settings to its flash memory.
member.remarks: For this instrument type, this method doesn't do anything, since the instrument automatically saves any changed settings to flash when it is undocked.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.getEquipmentSubType
member.summary: Returns the instrument's sub-type.
member.returns:
Possible Ventis Pro sub-types are as follows...
EquipmentSubType.VentisPro4
EquipmentSubType.VentisPro5

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.turnOnSensors(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commands the instrument to power on/off its sensors.
member.remarks: When called, this method powers on the instrument by setting its operating mode to . It powers off the instrument by setting its operating mode to .
member.param: Specify true to turn on, false to turn off.

Only applies if "on" parameter is true; otherwise, it is ignored.
If this paramter is True, then after the the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, it will wait for the warmup to complete before returning.
If this paramter is False, then after the instrument is commanded to warmup its sensors, this method will immediately return; i.e., it will not wait for the warmup to complete. The intention is to to have the instrument warm up its sensors in "the background" while the calling application continues to communicate with the instrument for other things.
member.exception: Thrown if instrument fails to warmup after a sufficient amount of time waiting for it to do.

When commanded to "warm up", this instrument type will run a self test. The self test may result in the instrument entering a SystemAlarm state that it will never leave until undocked. If this alarm state is detected, SystemAlarmException will be thrown. Its ErrorCode property will contain the error code that the instrument has reported.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.enableSensor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables/disables a sensor.
member.remarks: This method does nothing for this instrument type since the instrument does not support enabling/disabling of sensors. They are always enabled.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.isSensorEnabled(System.Int32)
member.returns: Always returns true. Sensors in this instrument type cannot be enabled or disabled; they're always enabled

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.setWirelessActiveChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets mask to specify which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.getWirelessActiveChannelMask
member.summary: Returns a mask specifying which active channels are allowed or not allowed to be used in active wireless frequency hopping. This is also referred to as 'blacklisted' channels.
member.returns:
Each bit of this returned value is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Bits are set to 1 for the allowed channels, or are set to 0 for the disallowed channels.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.setWirelessListeningPostChannelMask(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Sets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.
member.param:
Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.
Public channel(s) must be disallowed (set to 0) so that they are not used in active frequency hopping.
member.exception: Thrown if firmare version is less than 2.40 (LWV Changed from 3.0)

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.getWirelessListeningPostChannelMask
member.summary: Gets bit mask for channels that are used (1) / not used (0) by the Morrison Listening Post. This is also referred to as 'gateway channels'.

Each bit of this parameter is equivalent to one channel. (16 total bits: channels 0 to 15).
Set a bit to 1 to allow the channel, or set to 0 to disallow the channel.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.setWirelessCustomEncryptionKey(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the wireless module's custom encryption key.
member.param:
A hexadecimal string representing the encryption key's bytes. e.g. Maximum of 32 hex characters. (The encryption key is 128 bits. That equates to 16 bytes. 16 bytes represented as hex equates to 32 characters.)
If the passed-in string is longer than 32 characters, then the extra characters will be ignored.
If a null or empty string is passed in, then the module's custom encryption key will be set to all zeroes.
member.exception: If the passed-in string contains any non-hexadecimal characters.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.getWirelessCustomEncryptionKey
member.summary: Returns the wireless module's custom encryption key.
member.returns:
A hexadecimal string representing the encryption key's bytes.
If the encryption key is all zeroes, then an empty string is returned.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.VentisProDriver.getSensorBiasStatus
member.summary: Indicates if all the sensors that need to be biased are, and the instrument is ready for gas operations (zero, calibrate, bump, etc.).
member.remarks:
Some sensors, such as lead-free O2 sensors, are biased sensors that require constant power to get accurate readings. If the instrument's battery dies, then when the instrument is charged enough that the sensors can be turned on again, the biased sensors will likely be in OR for some time. Once the readings are low enough that the sensor is no longer in OR, it will still require some additional time before the readings are accurate enough where a reliable calibration or bump can be performed. Calibrating a biased sensor too soon can result in an improper calibration.
Docking stations needing to perform a gas operation (bump test, zeroing, calibration, etc.), should first call this getSensorBiasMethod before to determine if any sensors need biasing. If the method indicates that biasing is currently in progress, then this method should be repeated called until the biasing either completed, or it fails.
This method can be called for all instrument types. It will merely return SensorBiasStatus.Ready for instruments that do not use biased sensors, or if the VentisPro is older than v2.20 which is the version that support for biased sensors was added.
BEFORE CALLING THIS METHOD, IT IS IMPORTANT TO FIRST CALL , IN ORDER TO FIRST FULLY WARM UP THE SENSORS.
member.returns:
Docking stations should continually call this method while InProgress is returned.
Once Ready is returned, then the gas operation can proceed.
If Failed is returned, then the gas operation should not proceed.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster
member.summary: ModbusMaster provides ability to read/write from/to modbus registers.
member.remarks:
Note that ModbusMaster is an abstract class. It has (currently) four abstract methods that all subclasses must implement.... ReadRegister, WriteRegister, ReadMultipleRegisters and WriteMultipleRegisters.
Currently, there are two subclasses: The SerialIrdaModbusMaster subclass does binary modbus over a serial/IrDA port. The M40ModbusMaster implements the binary modbus protocol used for the M40 line of instruments.
The intent of this parent class is that if we ever have to use another form of Modbus for some future instrument (such as perhaps ASCII modbus?), then we could add another subclass to it (AsciiModbusMaster) that encapsulates that form of Modbus and implements the four abstract methods.
Each individual instrument driver needs to specify in its constructors which modbus master it needs use. Currently, all drivers use the SerialIrdaModbusMaster.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.Dispose
member.summary: Implementation of IDisposable. Call the virtual Dispose method. Suppress Finalization.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called by constructor and public Dispose in order to implement standard IDisposable design pattern.
member.param: true if being called explicitly by parameterless Dispose. false if being called by finalizing descructor.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.ReadRegister(System.UInt16,System.UInt16@)
member.summary: Reads the specified register from the instrument.
member.param: The modbus register number to read from.
The value read from the instrument will be placed into this short for return to the caller.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.WriteRegister(System.UInt16,System.UInt16,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes the passed in value to the specified register on the instrument.
member.param: The modbus register number to write to.
The value to write to the register.

If greater than zero, then after writing data to serial port, this method will sleep for this amount of time before attempting to read the instrument's response from the serial port.
Ignored if CommunicationModuleType is a docking station.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.ReadMultipleRegisters(System.UInt16,System.UInt16[],System.UInt16[]@)
member.summary: Reads a specified series of modbus registers from the instrument, and places the returned values into a specified array.
member.param: The number of registers to read. Why do we need this parameter? Can't we just use length of the registerNumbers array?
Values read from the instrument will be placed into this array for return to the caller. There's a one-to-one relationship assumed between the registerNumbers array and this array.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.WriteMultipleRegisters(System.UInt16,System.UInt16[],System.UInt16[])
member.summary: Writes a series of values to a series of modbus registers on the instrument.
member.param: The number of registers to write. Why do we need this parameter? Can't we just use length of the registerNumbers array?
The value to write to the registers. There's an one-to-one relationship assumed between the registerNumbers array and this array.

It is assumed the date/time is stored in the registers as number of seconds since midnight, 1/1/2000.

Sets the specified Hi/Lo registers to hold the specified calendar date/time.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.GetSensorDateTime(System.Int32,System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary:
Returns the calendar date/time stored in the specified HiLo registers.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ModbusMaster.GetSensorDateAsBytes(System.Int32,System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary: This reads out a date value in the format used by instruments such as the MX4 and iTrans (Register1 = Month and Day, Register2 = Year).
member.param: High byte = day of month, low byte = month
High byte is assumed to be 0, low byte = year (century is assumed to be 2000)
member.returns: DateTime contained in the specified registers. The time of day for the returned date is 12:00:00 AM

member.summary: Bit 1: High alarm.

member.summary: Bit 5: Zero failed alarm.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.AbortRequest
member.summary: Used to force driver to immediately stop communicating with the instrument.
member.remarks:
After constructing an instance of InstrumentDriver, you may optionally call SetAbortRequester to pass in an AbortRequest delegate.
Then, during communications with the the instrument, the driver will then periodically call this delegate to ask if the driver should abort what it's doing. It always calls this delegate immediately after it encounters any error in trying to communicate. As long as the delegate returns True, the driver will continue doing what it needs to do. If the delegate ever returns false, the driver will immediately abort and will throw a CommunicationsException
This is useful on the docking station, for example, in that if the instrument is undocked, the docking station can tell the driver to give up trying to communicate with the now missing instrument.
This may also be useful for Windows applications if those applications whish to have a some sort of "Stop" button to allow the user to stop a download of the Datalog, etc.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.CorruptHygieneException
member.summary: Thrown if an error is encountered trying to parse the datalog that is downloaded from an instrument.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.ConfigurationException
member.summary: Thrown when there a problem is encountered trying to factory configure an instrument.
member.remarks: Typically thrown by factory drivers' beginConfiguration() and endConfiguration() methods. For example, endConfiguration methods will typically throw this exception if the instrument remains stuck in "config mode".

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.Mx4Datalogger
member.summary: Downloads the datalog "packets" from instrument, then parses the packets to create datalog sessions.

remarks.para: From what I can tell, there are only 3 extremely minor code differences between the Mx4Datalogger and the Mx6Datalogger. The differneces are as follows...

1) The Mx6Datalogger knows what to do if it encounters a Response Factor packet. (See the code in Mx6Datalogger.ParseSessionPackets that calls ParseCustomResponseFactorHeader). This same code could also safely exist for MX4 datalog processing: just would never execute since it would never encounter response factor packets when parsing MX4 datalog data.
2) Mx6Datalogger.ParseSessionFooter has one extra line of code for parsing out the "comment" field.
3) The ParsePeriod method of each deal with the period's Timestamp field differently due to different formats for the timestamp in MX6 versus MX4.

member.name: T:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver
member.summary:
The GBPro driver extends the GBPlus driver, adding commands needed for docking on the DS2, and for DataLogging.
The "GBPro" driver is for use with Gas Badge Pro instruments.

remarks.para: The following info was provided by Jeff Marting in regards to having to "blast" the instrument with IrDA packets. Placing the info here for 'safe keeping'...

"If the GasBadge Pro is placed in a cradle when it is turned off, it will "peek" for an IrDA signal every 15 seconds. It will look for about 4 ms. If it doesnt see 4 edges on the IrDA signal during that time, it will disable the IrDA. If it sees the blast, the GasBadge Pro will wake up and enter "connected" mode.
If the instrument is powered on when docked, the process is similar, but it will look for communications every second instead of every 15.
Once the instrument is in connected mode, it will remain there until it hasnt received any commands for about 15 seconds. When that occurs, it will return to peeking mode."

It probably doesnt make much difference which baud rate is used for blasting, since the instrument only needs to see 4 edges in 4 ms. It would probably be simpler to use 9600, since that is the default speed for Modbus communication."

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.getInstrumentErrors
member.summary: Returns the errors that the instrument has logged.
member.returns:
The GasBadge Plus is only capable of reporting its current error state. It does not keep a running log of errors that have occurred in the past.
Therefor, if the instrument is currently in an error state, then this method will return an array containing a single InstrumentError instance that reprepresents that error.
Otherwise, this method will return an empty array.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.clearInstrumentErrors
member.summary:
Clear any instrument errors that stored on the instrument.
For the GasBadge Plus, this call will do nothing - Gas Badge Plus instruments does not have an error log to clear.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.getInstrumentDiagnostics
member.summary: Executes and returns the results of a series of instrument diagnostics tests.
member.returns:
An array of objects.
For this instrument type, the returned diagnostics have the following Codes...
BatteryVoltage
InstAlarmSeconds
InstLifeRemaining
InstOperationSeconds

member.summary: Returns whether the instrument's wireless feature is enabled or not (i.e. unlocked/locked).
member.remarks: The wireless feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the wireless hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasWirelessFeature returns true.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.enableWirelessFeature(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the instrument's wireless feature.
member.remarks: The wireless feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the wireless hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasWirelessFeature returns true.
member.param: True to unlock/enable the wireless features. False to lock/disable the wireless features.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.isBluetoothFeatureEnabled
member.summary: Returns whether the instrument's bluetooth feature is enabled or not(i.e. unlocked or locked).
member.remarks: The bluetooth feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the bluetooth hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasBluetoothFeature returns true.
member.returns: True if bluetooth features are unlocked/enabled. False if locked/disabled.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.enableBluetoothFeature(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the instrument's bluetooth feature.
member.remarks: The bluetooth feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the bluetooth hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasBluetoothFeature returns true.
member.param: True to unlock/enable the bluetooth features. False to lock/disable the bluetooth features.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.isiNetNowFeatureEnabled
member.summary: Returns whether the iNet Now feature is enabled or not(i.e. unlocked or locked).
member.remarks: The iNet Now feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the bluetooth hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasBluetoothFeature returns true.
member.returns: True if iNet Now feature is unlocked/enabled. False if locked/disabled.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusDriver.enableiNetNowFeature(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the iNet Now feature.
member.remarks: The iNet Now feature can be disabled/locked. This makes the feature's existence transparent to the user so that the bluetooth hardware can be installed but not accessible to the UI or Modbus. Ideally this should be called only if the HasBluetoothFeature returns true.
member.param: True to unlock/enable the iNet Now features. False to lock/disable the iNet Now features.
member.exception: Always thrown for this instrument type.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.connect(System.Boolean)
member.param:
If true is specified, then this method will initiate a "batch connection".
If false is specified, then non-batched connection is performed. It's recommended to use baud rate of 9600 for non-batched connections.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.PowerOnInstrument
member.summary: Helper function for PingInstrument(). Blasts instrument with IrDA packets to get its attention then issues it with a PowerUp command to turn it on.
member.returns: true if instrument turned itself on. false if we time out trying to turn it on

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.TalkWithInstrument
member.summary: Helper function for PingInstrument(). When initially turned on, instrument is at first unable to talk. Wait for instrument to start talking. We do this by continually asking it for it's instrument type until it starts responding.
member.returns: true if instrument started talking to us; false if we timeout waiting for instrument to talk.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.WarmupInstrument
member.summary: Helper method for PingInstrument. Waits for the instrument to warm up.

member.summary: Return a frame of datalog records. Each datalog record consists of a gas reading, a temperature, and an instrument status. member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.getHygiene

A new batch of uncompressed readings downloaded from the instrument.
member.returns: Number of readings passed in RawReadings array was deflated down to.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbProDriver.BuildDatalogHeaderTable(System.Collections.ArrayList@)
member.summary:
Return all datalog headers in the instrument. The datalog header is similar to the period header of previous instruments. A session will consist of one or more datalog headers.
The datalog header table is downloaded independently of the actual datalog.

member.name: M:ISC.Instrument.Driver.GbPlusFactoryDriver.InitConfiguration
member.summary: This method is called by beginConfiguration write after the instrument reports in in FactoryUnitialized mode.
